skills.name: Calculate the area of a circle, given the radius, leaving answers in terms of pi
Calculate the volume of a cylinder when the dimensions are given in the same units
Calculate the volume of other prisms when the dimensions are given in the same units

explanations.A: I think you may have multiplied the length, 9 cm, and the radius, 5 cm, to get 45. To find the volume of a prism, we need the area of the cross-section multiplied by the length.
explanations.B: Almost, but I think you may have added the length, 9 cm, to the area of the cross-section. What operation should we use instead?
explanations.C: The area of the base is 25ğœ‹. We multiply this by the height to get 25ğœ‹ Ã— 9 = 225ğœ‹ cmÂ³
explanations.D: I think you may have multiplied the length, 9 cm, by the circumference, 10Ï€ cm. To find the volume of a prism, we need the area of the cross-section multiplied by the length.

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you have forgotten to square the radius.
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you have used the diameter instead of the radius. Think about how we calculate the Area of a circle.

explanations.A: It looks like you have doubled the radius rather than squared it. Remember that squaring means we multiply the number by itself.
explanations.B: Vol of a prism = area of cross section x length. The area of the circle is 25pi, then x 10 to find the volume of the cylinder. This gives 250pi.
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you have forgotten to square the radius.
explanations.D: Not quite, I think you have calculated the area of the circle. Think about our next step to turn this into the volume of the cylinder.
